# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Overview

USDA Rural Development administers specialized water and waste disposal programs providing financial and technical assistance to rural communities. These represent the only federal initiative exclusively focused on rural water infrastructure for communities with populations of 10,000 or fewer.

# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Rural Definition and Population Thresholds

### Standard Definition

- **USDA Water Programs:** 10,000 or fewer residents
- **SEARCH Program:** 2,500 or fewer residents
- **Census Bureau Definition:** Open country and settlements with fewer than 2,000 housing units and 5,000 residents

### Key Considerations

- Population thresholds vary by program
- Rural residents may live in metropolitan counties
- Eligibility verified through USDA Rural Development website address database
- Colonias (established before October 1, 1989) have special eligibility

# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Water and Waste Disposal Loan & Grant Program

### Program Purpose

The primary financing mechanism for rural water and sanitation projects, providing long-term, low-interest loans combined with grants to communities that cannot obtain adequate credit through conventional channels.

### Eligible Applicants

- State and local governmental entities
- Private nonprofit organizations
- Federally recognized tribes and tribal entities

### Service Area Requirements

- Rural areas and towns with 10,000 or fewer residents
- Tribal lands in rural areas
- Colonias (unincorporated communities established before October 1, 1989)

### Current Interest Rates (Q1 2026)

| Community Classification | Interest Rate |
|-------------------------|---------------|
| Poverty-level (lowest income) | 2.875% |
| Intermediate | 3.750% |
| Market rate (highest income) | 4.750% |

### Loan Terms

- Repayment period: up to 40 years based on useful facility life
- Maximum funding: No stated cap (based on need and fund availability)
- May combine loans with grants when funds available

### Eligible Uses

**Core Infrastructure:**
- Drinking water systems (source, treatment, storage, distribution)
- Sanitary sewage systems (collection, transmission, treatment, disposal)
- Stormwater management systems
- Solid waste disposal infrastructure

**Related Activities:**
- Legal and engineering fees
- Land acquisition and water rights
- Equipment purchase and installation
- Permits and regulatory compliance
- Start-up costs and initial O&M
- Construction period interest
- Acquisition of existing facilities

### Application Process

- Applications accepted year-round
- Submit through RD Apply (online) or local USDA Rural Development office
- Level 2 eAuthentication ID required for online submission
- Contact local office before applying for technical guidance

chunk_text:
# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Emergency Community Water Assistance Grants (ECWAG)

### Program Purpose

Provides rapid response funding for communities experiencing acute water emergencies threatening safe, reliable drinking water availability.

### Eligible Emergencies

**Natural Disasters:**
- Drought conditions
- Flood events
- Earthquakes and earth movements
- Tornadoes and hurricanes

**Other Events:**
- Disease outbreaks (pathogenic contamination)
- Chemical spills, leaks, or seepage
- Equipment failures

### Key Requirements

- Federal disaster declaration NOT required
- Major decline in water quality/quantity within 2 years of application
- Or imminent decline anticipated
- Population 10,000 or fewer
- Median household income below state non-metropolitan MHI

### Funding Limits

| Grant Type | Maximum Amount |
|------------|----------------|
| Emergency Repairs (existing systems) | $150,000 |
| Water Transmission Lines | $150,000 |
| Water Source Infrastructure | $1,000,000 |

### Eligible Uses

- Waterline extensions and repairs
- Construction of new wells
- Reservoirs and transmission lines
- Water treatment plants
- Infrastructure to water supply point

### Application

- No matching funds required
- Applications accepted year-round
- Submit through RD Apply or local office
- Expedited processing for genuine emergencies

# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Rural Water Circuit Rider Program

### Program Purpose

Provides on-site, hands-on technical assistance to small rural water systems through experienced water utility professionals. Operated by National Rural Water Association under USDA contract.

### Program Structure

- 132 circuit riders serving all 50 states and Puerto Rico
- 24/7 availability at no cost to systems
- Activity-based training emphasizing ownership of solutions

### Assistance Topics

**Governance:**
- Board training for water system governance
- Fiduciary responsibilities

**Management and Finance:**
- Financial planning and rate-setting
- Accounting practices
- Financial sustainability analysis

**Operations:**
- Treatment process optimization
- Equipment maintenance
- System reliability improvement
- Infrastructure inspection

**Compliance:**
- Safe Drinking Water Act requirements
- Regulatory compliance assistance
- Quality control practices

**Security:**
- Physical facility security
- SCADA and cybersecurity protection

**Special Support:**
- Loan applications and reporting
- Disaster and emergency response

### Eligibility

- Water systems serving 10,000 or fewer people
- Public bodies, nonprofit corporations, or Indian tribes
- Must have legal authority to own/operate water facility

### California Access

**California Rural Water Association (CRWA)**
- Main Office: 1234 N. Market Boulevard, Sacramento, CA 95834
- Phone: 916.553.4900 / Toll-free: 800.833.0322
- Email: info@calruralwater.org
- Technical Assistance: Chris Rizzo, 909-714-6210

# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Special Evaluation Assistance for Rural Communities (SEARCH)

### Program Purpose

Provides grants to cover predevelopment feasibility studies, design work, and technical assistance that rural communities cannot afford but must complete before applying for construction financing.

### Eligibility Requirements

**Population:** 2,500 or fewer (more restrictive than standard programs)

**Income:** Must meet one of:
- Median household income below poverty line
- MHI less than 80% of statewide non-metropolitan MHI

**Applicants:**
- State and local governmental entities
- Nonprofit organizations
- Federally recognized tribes

### Funding Limits

- Maximum: $60,000 or 75% of predevelopment costs (whichever is lower)
- Based on demonstrated need
- Subject to fund availability

### Eligible Uses

**Predevelopment Planning:**
- Feasibility studies
- Preliminary design and engineering
- Cost estimates
- Technical application assistance

**Related Infrastructure Planning:**
- Public buildings and roads
- Bridges and utilities
- Other public improvements supporting water/waste facilities

### Important Conditions

- Cannot pay for already-completed work
- If project receives USDA construction loan/grant, SEARCH amount subtracted from grant eligibility
- If construction application denied, SEARCH grant does not require repayment

### Application

- Accepted year-round through local USDA Rural Development offices
section_title: Special Evaluation Assistance for Rural Communities (SEARCH)

# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Water and Waste Facility Loans/Grants for Colonias

### Program Purpose

Addresses specific needs of colonias—unincorporated communities established before October 1, 1989 with inadequate infrastructure and low-income populations.

### Eligibility

- State/local governments serving eligible colonias
- Nonprofit organizations
- Federally recognized tribes
- Rural areas with 10,000 or fewer population

### Requirements

- Significant health risks from inadequate water/waste services
- Matching funds usually required
- 100% grants possible under certain circumstances

### Eligible Uses

- Basic drinking water systems
- Waste disposal systems
- Stormwater drainage systems

chunk_text:
# USDA Rural Development Water Programs

## Disadvantaged Community Definitions

### USDA Classification

Interest rates tied to median household income:
- **Poverty-level:** Lowest MHI threshold = lowest rates (2.875%)
- **Intermediate:** Middle MHI threshold = moderate rates (3.750%)
- **Market:** Higher MHI threshold = highest rates (4.750%)

### California State Definition

- **Disadvantaged Community (DAC):** MHI < 80% of statewide MHI
- **Severely Disadvantaged Community (SDAC):** MHI < 60% of statewide MHI

### Benefits

Disadvantaged communities receive:
- Lower interest rates
- Higher grant percentages
- Enhanced eligibility for principal forgiveness
- Technical assistance priority

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

California operates multiple funding programs to provide immediate relief during water emergencies while building long-term water security. These programs prioritize disadvantaged communities, small water systems, and rural areas.

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Urgent Drinking Water Needs Program (UDWN)

### Overview
California's primary mechanism for immediate interim water supplies during emergencies caused by drought, contamination, or other disasters.

### Funding Source
Cleanup and Abatement Account (CAA) - funded by court judgments and administrative civil liabilities from water quality violations.

### Authorization
Water Code Section 13442 - allows State Water Board to address urgent drinking water needs.

### Eligible Applicants
- Public agencies (counties, cities)
- Tribal governments on CA Tribal Consultation List serving DACs
- Nonprofit organizations serving DACs
- Community water systems serving DACs

### Eligible Projects

**Interim Water Supplies**:
| Type | Maximum Allocation |
|------|-------------------|
| Bottled water (residential) | 60 gallons/household/month |
| Bottled water (schools) | 0.25 gallons/student-staff/day |
| Hauled water | 50 gallons/person/day |
| Water vending machines | Case-by-case |

**Emergency Infrastructure**:
- Well rehabilitation or replacement
- Emergency interties to adjacent systems
- Service line extensions
- Consolidation projects
- Treatment systems
- Equipment purchase/rental

**Construction Projects** (if <$500K):
- Serving small DACs or low-income households
- Addressing urgent compliance issues
- CEQA complete or exempt

### Approval Authority
- ≤$500K: DFA Deputy Director or Executive Director
- >$500K or controversial: Full State Water Board

### Application
- **Continuous basis** - no deadlines
- Email: DFA-CAA@waterboards.ca.gov
- Or submit through FAAST
- Approval: 2-8 weeks depending on complexity

### Reimbursement Process
- Costs reimbursed after incurrence (not advance funding)
- Grant agreement execution required before payment
- Submit reimbursement requests with documentation

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience (SAFER)

### Overview
Comprehensive program integrating emergency response, interim solutions, technical assistance, and long-term infrastructure development. Established by SB 200 (2019).

### Funding
- **Annual**: $130M from Safe and Affordable Drinking Water Fund
- **Supplemental**: DWSRF principal forgiveness, Prop 1, Prop 68

### Implementation Status (as of November 2024)
- Total assistance: $237.5M benefiting priority populations
- FY 2024: $76.4M (86% benefiting low-income communities)
- Projects funded: 119+

### Funding Priorities (in order)
1. Emergency/urgent funding needs
2. Water systems out of compliance or at-risk
3. Consolidation acceleration
4. Technical assistance for planning
5. Interim solutions for state small water systems and domestic wells
6. Racial equity distribution

### Eligible Applicants
- Public agencies and water utilities
- Nonprofits and mutual water companies
- Tribal governments
- State Water Board-appointed administrators
- Technical assistance providers
- Individual property owners (domestic wells)
- Groundwater sustainability agencies

### Eligible Projects
- Interim drinking water supplies
- Emergency repairs and improvements
- Technical assistance and capacity building
- Point-of-use/point-of-entry treatment (max 3 years)
- Operations and maintenance grants
- Long-term infrastructure development

### Application
- Continuous, year-round
- Pre-application through FAAST
- Staff guidance provided throughout process
section_title: Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience (SAFER)

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Small Community Drought Relief Program

### Funding
$305 million total:
- $200M: Substantive drought relief
- $20M: Household water storage tanks
- $5M: County drought resilience planning

### Eligibility
Communities NOT served by urban water suppliers (>3,000 customers or >3,000 AFY).

### Eligible Applicants
- Public agencies (counties, cities, special districts)
- Public utilities
- Colleges and universities
- Mutual water companies
- Nonprofit organizations
- Federally recognized tribes
- State-listed California tribes

### Eligible Projects

**Temporary Interim Solutions**:
- Hauled water delivery
- Temporary community water tanks
- Bottled water distribution
- Water vending machines

**Long-Term Infrastructure**:
- Water system storage improvements
- Infrastructure replacement (reducing losses)
- Backup power sources
- Well rehabilitation
- New well drilling
- Water recycling
- Conservation improvements
- System consolidation

### Application Process
- **First-come, first-served** (no competition)
- Email: SmallCommunityDrought@water.ca.gov
- Or mail to DWR Division of Regional Assistance
- Continuous review until funding depleted

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Urban and Multibenefit Drought Relief

### 2022 Urban Community Drought Relief
- **Funding**: ~$285M
- **DAC/Tribal Set-aside**: $85M minimum

### 2021 Urban and Multibenefit Drought Relief
- **Funding**: ~$190M
- **DAC/Tribal Set-aside**: $50M

### Eligible Applicants
- Public agencies and utilities
- Colleges and universities
- Mutual water companies
- 501(c)(3) nonprofits
- Regional water management groups
- Federally recognized California tribes
- State-listed California tribes

### Eligible Projects
- Hauled water and community tanks
- Bottled water distribution
- Water vending machines
- Emergency interties
- Well drilling/rehabilitation
- Permanent system connections
- Recycled water projects
- Fish and wildlife rescue
- Drought resiliency planning

### DAC Benefits
- Underrepresented communities exempt from match requirements

### Application
- **Competitive** - during specified windows
- Proposals evaluated against published criteria

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## DWSRF and Long-Term Infrastructure

### Drinking Water State Revolving Fund
Primary mechanism for lasting infrastructure improvements.

**FY 2025-26 Targets**:
- Loan commitments: $300M
- Grant/Principal Forgiveness: ~$1B

**Loan Terms**:
- Interest: Half of GO bond rate (2-3%)
- Term: Up to 30 years

**Grant Eligibility**:
- Small DAC, SDAC
- Expanded small DAC/SDAC
- Small non-DAC with MHI <150% statewide

### Lead Service Line Replacement
**Federal Funding**: $15B nationally
**California Received**: $250M (FY22) + $29M (FY23)

| Community Type | Terms |
|----------------|-------|
| DAC systems | Up to 100% principal forgiveness |
| Non-DAC | 0% interest loans |

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Proposition 4 (2024 Climate Bond)

### Water Security Funding
~$1.07 billion expected starting Fall 2025 for:
- Safe drinking water
- Drought resilience
- Flood protection
- Water resilience

### IRWM Allocation
$100M to DWR by FY 2027-28:
- FY 2025-26: $500K
- FY 2026-27: $3M
- FY 2027-28+: $96M

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Federal Programs

### USDA Emergency Community Water Assistance Grants (ECWAG)

**Purpose**: Help rural communities prepare for or recover from water emergencies.

**Eligible Emergencies** (no federal disaster declaration required):
- Drought or flood
- Earthquake, tornado, hurricane
- Disease outbreaks
- Chemical spills

**Grant Amounts**:
| Type | Maximum |
|------|---------|
| Water transmission line grants | $150,000 |
| Water source grants | $1,000,000 |

**Eligibility**:
- Rural areas (population ≤10,000)
- Tribal lands in rural areas
- Colonias
- MHI below state non-metropolitan median

**Application**: Year-round through RD APPLY or local USDA Rural Development offices

### Tribal Water Security

**Coordinating Agencies**:
- Indian Health Service (rapid short-term assistance)
- USDA (extended emergency water supply)
- State Water Board Division of Financial Assistance
- County Office of Emergency Services
- Cal OES Tribal Advisor

**California Programs for Tribes**:
- UDWN (serving DACs)
- SAFER program
- Small Community Drought Relief
- Urban Drought Relief (set-asides)

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Eligibility Definitions

### Disadvantaged Community (DAC)
Annual median household income <80% statewide MHI (~$56,982)

### Severely Disadvantaged Community (SDAC)
Annual median household income <60% statewide MHI (~$43,737)

### Small Community
- SCDW: ≤10,000 population OR ≤3,300 connections
- SCWW: <20,000 population
- Drought Relief: Not served by urban supplier (>3,000 customers)

### Urban Water Supplier
>3,000 customers OR >3,000 AFY (Water Code 10617)

# Emergency and Drought Water Funding Programs

## Quick Reference: Which Program to Use

| Situation | Program |
|-----------|---------|
| Immediate water outage | UDWN |
| Contamination emergency | UDWN, SAFER |
| Drought - small community | Small Community Drought Relief |
| Drought - urban/regional | Urban/Multibenefit Drought Relief |
| Long-term infrastructure | DWSRF, SAFER |
| Consolidation project | SAFER, DWSRF |
| Rural community (<10,000) | USDA ECWAG |
| PFAS contamination | DWSRF Emerging Contaminants |

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

The Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) program is California's primary collaborative approach to regional water management, providing over $2 billion in state funding since 2002 to implement more than 1,450 integrated, multi-benefit water projects statewide.

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Program Overview

IRWM encourages water agencies across watersheds to collaborate in managing regional water resources rather than operating in isolation. The program provides funding for implementation projects that:

- Support coordinated regional water management
- Set regional priorities for water infrastructure investment
- Improve regional self-reliance
- Reduce dependence on the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta

Communities receiving IRWM grants have matched state funding at an average ratio of **2.5:1**, mobilizing over $5 billion when combined with local contributions.

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Regional Structure

### Coverage
- 48 officially accepted IRWM regions
- 87% of California's land area
- 99% of state population

### Funding Areas
California is divided into 12 hydrologic region-based Funding Areas for Proposition 1 grants:

- North Coast
- Sacramento Valley
- San Francisco Bay
- Central Coast
- South Coast
- Colorado River
- (and 6 additional regional areas)

Some areas have **Funding Area Coordinating Committees (FACCs)** to manage distribution across multiple IRWM regions (e.g., Tri-County FACC for San Diego Funding Area).

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Regional Water Management Groups (RWMGs)

Each IRWM region operates through an RWMG that:

- Develops and adopts the regional IRWM Plan
- Coordinates stakeholder involvement
- Evaluates and prioritizes projects
- Submits grant applications to DWR

### RWMG Composition
Must include at least three local agencies, with two having statutory authority over water supply/management. Typical members:
- Cities and counties
- Water districts and special districts
- Nonprofit organizations
- Tribal entities
- Environmental groups
- Disadvantaged community representatives

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Types of IRWM Grants

### Planning Grants
- Purpose: Develop or update IRWM Plans
- Funding: Approximately $5M total (modest compared to implementation)
- 2016 awards: $4.2M across 15 proposals
- Activities: Surveys, stakeholder engagement, technical analysis

### Implementation Grants
- Purpose: Construction of water management infrastructure
- Proposition 1 funding: $510M total authorization
- Round 1 (2020): $211M to 42 regions
- Round 2 (2023): $201M to 40 regions
- Total awarded: Over $403M

### DAC Involvement Grants
- Purpose: Engage disadvantaged communities in IRWM planning
- Funding: $51M (10% reservation per Funding Area)
- Activities: Outreach, capacity building, needs assessments

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Eligible Project Types

- Water reuse and recycling (potable and non-potable)
- Water conservation and efficiency
- Surface and underground storage
- Groundwater recharge and cleanup
- Regional water conveyance
- Watershed protection and restoration
- Stormwater and flood management
- Conjunctive use programs
- Water desalination
- Decision support tools
- Water quality improvements

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Disadvantaged Community Requirements

### Definitions
- **DAC**: Median household income <80% statewide MHI ($48,706 threshold)
- **SDAC**: Median household income <60% statewide MHI

### Set-Asides
- Minimum 10% of each Funding Area's allocation reserved for DAC projects
- Round 2: $93M (46%) directed to DAC/tribal benefits

### Match Waivers
For DAC implementation projects seeking Prop 84 or Prop 1 funds:
- Standard 25% match requirement may be **waived entirely**
- Critical for communities with limited financial capacity

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Statewide Priorities

DWR evaluates projects against five statewide priorities:

1. **Natural Infrastructure**: Forests, floodplains, wetlands for sustainable water management
2. **Regional Approaches**: Watershed-level coordination, system interties
3. **Drought Preparedness**: Conservation, recycling, conjunctive use, desalination
4. **Climate Resilience**: Adaptation, greenhouse gas reduction, sea level rise preparation
5. **Partnerships**: Local, federal, tribal collaboration

# Integrated Regional Water Management (IRWM) Funding

## Application Process

### Region Acceptance Process (RAP)
Before applying for implementation grants, regions must:
1. Submit documentation of geographic boundaries
2. Demonstrate governance structure
3. Identify Lead Agency
4. Show minimum agency membership

48 regions currently accepted; status maintained unless boundaries change.

### IRWM Plan Requirements
Projects must be explicitly listed in an adopted IRWM Plan consistent with 2016 standards. Plans must address:
- Regional water assessments
- Governance and stakeholder involvement
- Environmental considerations
- Climate change vulnerabilities
- Disadvantaged community strategies

### Implementation Grant Applications

Applications submitted through Proposal Solicitation Packages (PSPs) that specify:
- Evaluation criteria
- Funding priorities
- Maximum grant amounts
- Match requirements
- Application deadlines

Required documentation:
- Detailed work plans
- Line-item budgets
- Environmental review (CEQA)
- Letters of support
- Project schedules

|---------|-------------------|
| Proposition 1 Implementation | 25% minimum |
| Proposition 84 Implementation | 25% minimum |
| Proposition 1E SWFM | 50% (cannot be waived) |
| DAC Projects (Prop 84/1) | May be waived |

Acceptable match sources:

# California Proposition 1 (2014 Water Bond)

Proposition 1, the Water Quality, Supply, and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014, authorized $7.545 billion in general obligation bonds for California's most comprehensive water infrastructure investment. Approved by voters with a 67-33 margin in November 2014, the bond has funded over 673 projects statewide.

# California Proposition 1 (2014 Water Bond)

## Bond Allocation by Chapter

| Chapter | Purpose | Amount | Committed |
|---------|---------|--------|-----------|
| Chapter 5 | Clean, safe, reliable drinking water | $520M | $508.5M |
| Chapter 6 | Rivers, lakes, streams, watersheds | $1.495B | $1.453B |
| Chapter 7 | Regional water security, climate | $810M | $789.9M |
| Chapter 8 | Water storage and drought preparedness | $2.7B | $2.646B |
| Chapter 9 | Water recycling | $725M | $706.4M |
| Chapter 10 | Groundwater sustainability | $900M | $798.1M |
| Chapter 11 | Flood management | $395M | $387.1M |

As of 2025, $7.519 billion (99.7%) has been committed, with only $25.7 million remaining unallocated.

# California Proposition 1 (2014 Water Bond)

SWRCB administers Proposition 1 funds through the Division of Financial Assistance for:

- **Water Storage Investment Program**: $2.7B (largest allocation) for public benefit storage projects
- **Flood Management**: $395M for Delta levees and statewide flood control
- **Agricultural Water Efficiency**: $3M pilot program (awarded to North San Joaquin WCD)

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

This document covers innovative financing mechanisms for California water infrastructure beyond traditional grants, including environmental impact bonds, green bonds, public-private partnerships, water markets, and pay-for-success models.

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## Environmental Impact Bonds (EIBs)

Environmental Impact Bonds link investor returns directly to environmental outcomes, representing a revolutionary departure from traditional municipal bond financing.

### How EIBs Work

**Basic Structure:**
1. Private investors provide upfront capital
2. Funds transfer to project implementer
3. Environmental intervention produces outcomes
4. Beneficiaries reimburse costs plus interest based on performance
5. Interest rate can be predetermined or performance-based

**Key Distinction from Green Bonds:**
- Green bonds: Fixed repayment regardless of project performance
- EIBs: Compensation indexed to forecasted and realized environmental benefits

**Repayment Sources:**
- Cost savings (reduced cleanup costs, more efficient regulatory compliance)
- Financial benefits (reduced flooding, enhanced revenues, increased tax base)

### DC Water: America's First EIB (Model Case Study)

**Background:**
- Combined sewer overflows dumped 2.5 billion gallons annually into DC rivers
- 2005 EPA consent decree required addressing sewer overflow
- Initial plan: Multi-billion dollar grey infrastructure

**EIB Structure:**
- **Bond Amount:** $25 million
- **Investors:** Goldman Sachs and Calvert Impact Capital
- **Project:** 25 acres of green infrastructure pilot
- **Transaction Intermediary:** Quantified Ventures

**Green Infrastructure Components:**
- Permeable pavement
- Green roofs
- Landscaped retention facilities

**Performance Targets:**
- Capture approximately 650,000 gallons of water annually
- Reduce runoff into Rock Creek by targeted amount

**Results:**
- Green infrastructure reduced runoff by nearly 20% over five years
- Outperformed expectations
- Spring 2021: Full repayment with no penalty
- Demonstrated EIBs work in water infrastructure

**Co-Benefits:**
- New green spaces at multiple locations
- Construction employment opportunities
- Green infrastructure workforce certification program

### Other EIB Examples

**Atlanta (2018):**
- Department of Watershed Management announced EIBs for green infrastructure
- Partnership with municipal broker-dealer Neighborly
- Focus: Flood resilience in Proctor Creek Watershed

**Baltimore (2018):**
- Department of Public Works adopted EIB for stormwater
- Funded 90 landscaping projects in 30+ neighborhoods
- Supported by Chesapeake Bay Foundation and Kresge Foundation

**Louisiana:**
- Environmental Defense Fund + Quantified Ventures
- Evaluating EIB feasibility for coastal wetland restoration
- Potential Gulf-wide replication

### Accessing EIB Financing

**Critical First Steps:**
1. Quantify environmental outcomes with investor-grade precision
2. Develop clear performance metrics
3. Establish monitoring protocols and third-party evaluation

**Key Partners Needed:**
- Engineers (project design, monitoring protocols)
- Financial advisors (bond structure, investor identification)
- Legal counsel (contracts, repayment terms)
- Policy experts (regulatory navigation)
- EIB developers like Quantified Ventures

**Business Case Requirements:**
- Payors willing and able to repay based on outcomes
- Service providers with implementation capacity
- Reasonable completion timeline

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## Green Bonds for Water Infrastructure

Green bonds are fixed-income securities with proceeds earmarked for environmentally beneficial projects.

### Green Bond Principles (GBP)

**Four Core Components:**
1. **Use of Proceeds:** Clear description in legal documentation
2. **Project Evaluation and Selection:** Process for identifying eligible projects
3. **Management of Proceeds:** Tracking and allocation systems
4. **Reporting:** Transparency on project implementation and impact

### Climate Bonds Standard

The Climate Bonds Initiative provides independent verification for water infrastructure bonds:

**Coverage:**
- Built (grey) water infrastructure
- Natural (green or hybrid) water infrastructure
- Industrial water efficiency and reuse
- Catchment/watershed restoration
- Large-scale water supply development

### San Francisco PUC: Leading California Green Bond Issuer

**Track Record:**
- First-ever Climate Bonds Standard Certified Water Bond
- FY 2015-2023: Over $3.7 billion in certified green bonds (Water/Wastewater)
- Over $100 million in self-certified green bonds (Power enterprise)

**July 2024 Issuance:**
- **Total:** Nearly $1 billion
- **Taxable Green Bonds:** ~$432 million
- **Tax-Exempt Green Bonds:** ~$548 million
- **Purpose:** Wastewater and stormwater system upgrades

**Sewer System Improvement Program (SSIP) Projects:**
- Wastewater treatment improvements
- Hydraulic and drainage improvements in flood-prone neighborhoods
- Advanced rainfall and operational decision systems
- Green infrastructure (permeable pavements, bioretention, stormwater planters)

**UN Sustainable Development Goals Addressed:**
- SDG 3: Good Health and Well-being
- SDG 6: Clean Water and Sanitation
- SDG 7: Affordable and Clean Energy
- SDG 9: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
- SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities
- SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production
- SDG 13: Climate Action
- SDG 14: Life Below Water
- SDG 15: Life on Land

### California State Water Bonds

**Proposition 1 (2014):**
- **Amount:** $7.545 billion
- **Purpose:** Water storage, groundwater sustainability, watershed protection, water recycling, stormwater capture
- **Focus:** Mix of supply and ecosystem investments for drought resilience

**Proposition 68 (2018):**
- **Amount:** $4.1 billion
- **Purpose:** Parks, natural resources, climate adaptation, water infrastructure
- **Strong Equity Focus:** Set-asides for disadvantaged communities

**Proposition 4 (2024):**
- **Amount:** $10 billion
- **Purpose:** Climate and water bond (largest to date)
- **Water Allocation:** ~$2 billion for drinking water protection
- **Coverage:** Coastal resilience, flood planning, extreme heat, nature-based solutions, sustainable agriculture, drought resilience, forest health

### Accessing Green Bond Funding

**State Bond Process:**
1. Legislature proposes bond measures
2. Voters approve during elections
3. State sells debt in capital markets
4. Proceeds placed into specified funds
5. State agencies distribute grants to communities

**Key Distributing Agencies:**
- Department of Fish and Wildlife
- State Water Resources Control Board
- Department of Parks and Recreation
- Department of Water Resources
- Regional entities

**Community Actions:**
- Monitor agency announcements for application periods
- Develop detailed project proposals
- Demonstrate alignment with bond purposes
- Show service to disadvantaged communities
- Document measurable environmental outcomes

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## Public-Private Partnerships (P3s)

P3s involve private entities assuming responsibility for designing, financing, building, operating, and/or maintaining infrastructure projects.

### California Legal Framework

**California Infrastructure Finance Act (IFA):**
- Government Code section 5956 et seq.
- Allows P3s for fee-producing local government projects
- Competitive negotiation process required

**Eligible Entities:**
- Cities, counties
- School districts, community college districts
- Public districts
- Joint powers authorities
- Transportation commissions/authorities
- Other public/municipal corporations

**Eligible Projects:**
- Irrigation, drainage
- Energy/power production
- Water supply treatment and distribution
- Flood control
- Sewage treatment, disposal, water recycling
- Municipal improvements

**AB 164 (2013):** Required payment bonds and performance bonds for P3 projects

### Rialto Water Services: California P3 Pioneer

**Structure:**
- Long-term concession agreement
- Private partner constructs facilities within first 5 years
- Then operates and maintains systems
- Optimizes life-cycle costs

**Key Partners:**
- **Rialto Water Services** (owned by Ullico affiliate and Table Rock Capital)
- **Ullico:** Labor-owned financial services, prioritizes quality jobs
- **Table Rock Capital:** P3 infrastructure finance specialists
- **Veolia North America:** Operational partner (operated Rialto wastewater since 2003)

**Impact:**
- Estimated 445 construction jobs during development
- Accelerated infrastructure improvements
- City maintained control through Proposition 218 vote on rate increases

### Carlsbad Desalination Plant

**Overview:**
- Nation's largest seawater desalination facility
- **Capacity:** 50 million gallons per day (average); 54 MGD at full capacity
- **Operator:** Poseidon Resources
- **Technology:** Reverse osmosis

**Innovative Financing:**
- True partnership model
- Long-term water purchase agreement with San Diego County Water Authority
- First major California infrastructure project to eliminate carbon footprint

**Recognition:**
- Desalination Deal of the Year 2013 (Global Water Intelligence)
- North American Water Deal of the Year (Project Finance Magazine)
- Far West Deal of the Year 2013 (The Bond Buyer)

### P3 Benefits

| Benefit | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Risk Transfer | Performance-based contracts transfer design, construction, operating risk |
| Project Acceleration | Fast-track design and construction |
| Access to Capital | Private sector funding addresses public budget constraints |
| Innovation | Performance incentives drive technological advancement |
| Operational Efficiency | Life-cycle cost optimization |

### P3 Challenges

| Challenge | Consideration |
|----------|---------------|
| Complexity | Extensive legal, financial, procurement work required |
| Capacity | Smaller municipalities may lack internal expertise |
| Cost Concerns | May result in higher total ownership costs |
| Public Perception | Fears about privatization, loss of control |
| Risk Allocation | Balancing public goals with private risk appetite |

### Accessing P3 Structures

**Assessment Questions:**
- Does project have clear revenue streams?
- Is there significant design/operational complexity?
- Are capital requirements substantial?
- Does project have long operational lifespan?

**Recommended Steps:**
1. Conduct feasibility study comparing P3 to traditional procurement
2. Engage legal counsel with P3 experience
3. Review statutory authorities for specific community/project type
4. Prepare detailed project specifications
5. Establish credible revenue mechanisms
6. Identify potential private sector partners
7. Build stakeholder consensus on approach and rate structures

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## Water Markets and Trading

California water markets enable trading of water rights and supplies between willing buyers and sellers.

### California Surface Water Market

**Evolution:**
- Began in early 1980s
- Expanded significantly during 1987-1992 drought
- State-run Drought Water Bank spurred development

**Current Scale:**
- Approximately 1.5 million acre-feet traded annually
- About 4% of all water used by cities and farms

**Transaction Geography:**
- 46% within same county
- 26% within same region

**Transaction Types:**
- Short-term transfers (drought-year purchases)
- Long-term bilateral agreements
- Water banks and pools (intermediary arrangements)
- Multi-party transfers

**Participants:**
- Farms hold ~4x more water rights than cities (primary sellers)
- Growing cities are major buyers (especially San Joaquin Valley, Southern California)
- Southern California cities now receive ~15% of supplies from trades

### Environmental Water Purchases

- Over 6 million acre-feet acquired for environmental purposes (1982-2019)
- 17% of total market flows
- Supports wildlife refuges, fish flows, Salton Sea salt reduction
- Funding from state/federal taxpayers and water users

### Groundwater Trading and SGMA

**Sustainable Groundwater Management Act (SGMA):**
- Requires Groundwater Sustainability Agencies (GSAs) to develop sustainability plans
- Creates framework for groundwater trading programs

**How Groundwater Trading Works:**
1. Pumpers receive allocations (allowances to extract specific amounts)
2. Pumpers can use allocation individually or trade with others
3. Users implementing conservation create tradeable surplus
4. Market creates flexibility for constrained areas

**GSA Authority:**
- Developing trading programs is voluntary and locally driven
- GSAs best positioned for local context
- Responsible for protecting vulnerable users (natural resources, small farms, disadvantaged communities)

### Mojave Basin Groundwater Market

**Most Liquid California Groundwater Market:**
- Established through 1990s court adjudication
- Over $400 million in economic gains from adjudication

**Market Characteristics:**
- Alto subarea: Highest trading activity and prices
- Baja subarea: Second-highest volume
- Spot market volume exceeded 20,000 acre-feet since 1990s

**Participants:**
- Agriculture
- Recreational lake operators
- Industrial operations (mining, cement)
- Environmental interests
- Mojave Water Agency (addressing overdraft)
- California Department of Fish and Wildlife (habitat protection)

### Groundwater Banking

**Metropolitan Water District Example:**
- Increased groundwater storage capacity 13x since 1990
- Partnerships along State Water Project and Colorado River Aqueduct
- In dry years: Partners pump stored water or provide exchange supplies

**Antelope Valley-East Kern High Desert Water Bank:**
- Storage capacity: Up to 280 acre-feet
- Dry-year supply: Up to 50 acre-feet
- MWD funded monitoring/production wells, turnouts, pipelines, recharge basins

### Groundwater Sustainability Fees

**Santa Rosa Plain GSA Example:**
- Self-funded through groundwater sustainability fee
- 2024-2025 Rate: $43.65 per acre-foot
- Rural residential (0.5 acre-feet/year): $21.83 annual fee

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## Pay-for-Success Models

Pay-for-Success (PFS) contracting defines desired outcomes and restructures payments to align with results achieved.

### How PFS Works

**Basic Structure:**
1. Private investors fund initial project costs
2. Service providers implement on-the-ground work
3. Independent evaluator assesses performance
4. Beneficiaries reimburse investors based on outcomes

**Key Benefits:**
- Increases likelihood of achieving desired outcomes
- Documents return on investment clearly
- Informs future funding decisions
- Shifts risk to private sector

### Water Sector PFS Applications

**Clean Water Commerce Act (2017, expanded 2021):**
- Authorized through 2030
- Purchases $20 million/year in nitrogen reduction outcomes
- Units of environmental improvement paid for after production
- Cuts paperwork, increases competition, drives down costs

**Maryland Cross-State Innovation:**
- $25 million transfer to Susquehanna River Basin Commission
- Purchases nitrogen reduction outcomes in either state's watershed
- First time Maryland spent state money on projects in another state

### Anne Arundel County PFS Program (2018)

**Full Delivery of Water Quality Improvements:**
- Expedites waterway restoration through public-private partnerships
- Funds stormwater Best Management Practice construction
- Supports NPDES MS4 permit goals, Chesapeake Bay TMDL, Clean Water Act

**How It Works:**
1. Contractors front initial implementation costs
2. County reimburses after construction and verification
3. Projects verified to generate water quality credits
4. Competitive proposals prioritized by readiness

**Results:**
- Resilient, cost-effective project pipeline
- Significantly cheaper than previous traditional contracts
- Substantial progress toward permit requirements

### North Carolina: PFS Pioneer

**Division of Mitigation Services In-Lieu Fee Programs:**
- Purchases environmental outcomes for responsible development
- Watershed approach maximizes environmental returns
- Aggregates funding from permittees needing to offset impacts
- Creates larger, more beneficial restoration than one-off projects

### Accessing PFS Financing

**Business Case Requirements:**
- Clear identification of project impacts and benefiting stakeholders
- Benefits outweigh costs
- Willingness to pay for ecosystem services delivered
- Payors able to repay investors
- Service providers with capacity and expertise
- Reasonable completion timeline

**Key Steps:**
1. Develop robust outcome quantification
2. Establish third-party verification mechanisms
3. Structure flexible repayment (below-market initially, ramps up with performance)
4. Engage experienced PFS transaction developers

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## State Revolving Funds

### Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

**Eligible Projects:**
- Wastewater treatment plants
- Sewer systems
- Nonpoint source projects
- Estuary projects

**Terms:**
- Interest rate: Half of most recent General Obligation Bond rate
- Most common term: 30 years
- Significant savings vs. traditional municipal bonds

**Eligible Applicants:**
- Government entities
- Tribes
- Nonprofit organizations

### Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

**Purpose:** Assist public water systems with compliance projects

**Terms:**
- Interest rate: Half of most recent General Obligation Bond rate
- Most common term: 30 years

**Principal Forgiveness Available for:**
- Small disadvantaged communities
- Small severely disadvantaged communities
- Expanded small disadvantaged/severely disadvantaged communities
- Small non-disadvantaged communities (MHI < 150% statewide median)

### Bipartisan Infrastructure Law Funding

- DWSRF: $250 million (FY 2022) for lead service line replacement
- FY 2024-2025: $1.4 billion from Revolving Funds and federal programs
- Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act: ~$730 million contribution

# Alternative Financing Mechanisms

## Strategic Recommendations

### Financing Mechanism Selection

| Situation | Best Mechanism |
|-----------|----------------|
| Green infrastructure with performance uncertainty | Environmental Impact Bond |
| Large capital project, environmental focus | Green Bond |
| Complex project, limited public capacity | Public-Private Partnership |
| Flexible supply management | Water Market/Trading |
| Outcomes-based stormwater projects | Pay-for-Success |
| Standard infrastructure, disadvantaged community | State Revolving Fund |

### Multi-Mechanism Approach

California's $21 billion water infrastructure need requires combining mechanisms:
1. Use SRF loans for core infrastructure
2. Layer green bonds for environmental components
3. Apply EIBs for innovative/uncertain elements
4. Leverage water markets for supply flexibility
5. Access foundation grants for planning and capacity building

### Key Success Factors

1. **Quantified Outcomes:** All innovative mechanisms require measurable metrics
2. **Risk Allocation:** Clear understanding of who bears what risk
3. **Revenue Certainty:** Credible payment sources for investor confidence
4. **Technical Capacity:** Expertise for structuring complex deals
5. **Stakeholder Engagement:** Community support for rate/fee structures

# Technical Assistance Providers

This document covers organizations that provide technical assistance to California water systems, especially small and disadvantaged communities, including their services, eligibility requirements, and how to access support.

# Technical Assistance Providers

## Overview: California's Drinking Water Crisis

Over one million Californians currently lack safe drinking water, with another million at risk. Technical assistance providers fill a critical gap between regulatory agencies enforcing standards and communities struggling to meet them.

**Common Challenges Addressed:**
- Groundwater contamination (arsenic, nitrates, uranium, pesticides, 1,2,3-TCP)
- Aging infrastructure
- Limited budgets and understaffed operations
- Regulatory compliance
- Access to capital financing

- Small/low-cost needs enabling funding applications

### Eligibility Definitions

- **Small Communities:** Population fewer than 10,000
- **Disadvantaged Communities:** MHI below 80% of statewide median

### How to Access

Submit online Technical Assistance Request Form to State Water Board's Division of Financial Assistance

**Note:** Demand significantly exceeds capacity. Not all requests can be accommodated.

### Contact Information

- **Website:** waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/tech_asst_funding.html

# Technical Assistance Providers

## SAFER Program (Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience)

### Program Overview

- **Established:** Senate Bill 200 (2019)
- **Purpose:** Ensure one million Californians without safe water receive access
- **Funding:** Up to $130 million per year for up to ten years

### Eligible Applicants

- Public agencies
- Nonprofit organizations
- Public utilities
- Mutual water companies
- California Native American tribes
- Administrators
- Groundwater sustainability agencies

### Program Priorities

1. Emergency/urgent funding needs
2. Community water systems and schools out of compliance
3. Accelerating consolidations
4. Interim solutions for state small water systems and domestic wells

### Technical Assistance Integration

SAFER provides up to $130 million annually specifically for:
- Technical assistance
- Planning
- Feasibility studies

This TA funding enables communities to complete preliminary work required before accessing capital funding.

### Program Impact

- Distributed over $1.6 billion in grants
- 320 water systems serving 3.3 million people returned to compliance
- $20 million invested in hauled water for drought-impacted households

### Domestic Well Support

Recognizes domestic well users lack governance structures:
- Domestic well testing
- Replacement water provisions
- Consolidation with small water systems

### Recent Achievements

**SAFER Extended Through 2045:**
- Governor Newsom and Legislature three-party deal
- Continuous appropriation of up to $130 million annually
- Additional $180 million from Proposition 4

### Contact Information

- **Website:** waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/sustainable_water_solutions

# Technical Assistance Providers

## Environmental Justice Technical Assistance Framework

California has integrated environmental justice principles throughout state water programs.

### Central Coast Water Board Environmental Justice Program

**Resolution R3-2017-0004:**
- Adopts human right to water as core value
- Implements principles throughout board programs

**Action Plan Initiatives:**
- Environmental Justice, Racial Equity, and Tribal Engagement
- Addresses disparities
- Ensures meaningful engagement of disadvantaged and tribal communities

### Central Coast Programs

- Central Coast Drinking Water Well Testing Program
- Regional Bottled Water Program
- Region 3 Wastewater Consolidation Program
- Water needs assessments with DAC and tribal involvement

### Environmental Justice TA Providers (Central Coast)

- Community Water Center (Central Coast office)
- Rural Community Assistance Corporation
- California Rural Legal Assistance
- Central Coast Climate Justice Network
- Central Coast Alliance United for a Sustainable Economy

# Technical Assistance Providers

## State Funding Programs Accessed Through TA Providers

### Safe and Affordable Drinking Water Fund

- Up to $130 million/year
- Supports planning, construction, TA, emergency drinking water
- Focus: Small, rural, disadvantaged communities

### Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

- Low-interest loans
- Principal forgiveness for disadvantaged communities
- Interest rate: Half of GO Bond rate
- Term: Up to 30 years

### Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

- Wastewater treatment financing
- Similar terms to DWSRF

### Proposition Funding

**Proposition 68:**
- $4.058 billion for water quality, supply, infrastructure

**Proposition 4:**
- $180 million toward safe drinking water and wastewater projects

**Proposition 1:**
- $7.545 billion for water projects
- Emphasis on TA for small disadvantaged communities

### Small Community Drought Relief Program

- **Amount:** $200 million
- **Purpose:** Resiliency measures and infrastructure improvements
- **Eligibility:** Small water suppliers, rural communities with drought impacts

**Example: West Goshen Consolidation:**
- Community Water Center helped secure $3.45 million
- Cal Water extended service to 44 customers
- Private wells had failed or become contaminated

### California Financing Coordinating Committee (CFCC) Handbook

Annual compilation of financial and technical resources from multiple agencies:
- Drinking water
- Wastewater
- Water quality and supply
- Water conservation

Available at: events.rcac.org (search CFCC Handbook)

# Technical Assistance Providers

## Accessing Technical Assistance: Step-by-Step

### Direct Provider Contact

1. Visit provider website
2. Submit online assistance request form
3. Provide water system details, challenges, assistance needs
4. Provider reviews and prioritizes based on capacity and need
5. Initial assessment and scoping meeting
6. Tailored on-site technical assistance delivery
7. Ongoing relationship for continued support

### State-Administered Programs

1. Submit online Technical Assistance Request Form to State Water Board
2. Division of Financial Assistance reviews and prioritizes
3. Contracted TA providers assigned based on system needs

### Training Programs

RCAC and CRWA publish training calendars:
- Community members and operators can attend without individual requests
- Provides continuing education credits for operator certification
- Flexible scheduling (online and in-person options)

### Important Notes

- Demand exceeds capacity - prioritization is necessary
- Inquire about timelines when submitting requests
- Multiple providers may serve your region
- TA often positions communities for capital funding access
- Planning and feasibility work qualifies for SAFER funding

# Technical Assistance Providers

## Programs for Tribal Communities

### RCAC Tribal Circuit Rider Program

- Dedicated TA for tribal water systems
- California, Arizona, Nevada coverage
- Works directly with tribal water managers
- Culturally appropriate approaches
- Respects unique governance structures

### Native American Water Master's Association

- Professional development for tribal utility staff
- Networking with peers facing similar challenges
- Operated by RCAC

### SAFER Tribal Eligibility

- California Native American tribes explicitly eligible
- Specific outreach and engagement processes
- Prioritized within state programs

## Strategic Recommendations

### When to Contact Each Provider

| Situation | Best Provider |

# Water-Focused Foundations

This document covers philanthropic foundations dedicated specifically to water issues, with details on their California programs, funding mechanisms, and application processes.

# Water-Focused Foundations

## Water Foundation

The Water Foundation is the only intermediary foundation in the United States solely focused on water and its interconnected impacts, serving as a strategic bridge between donors and on-the-ground organizations.

### Mission and Focus

The Water Foundation addresses water challenges across multiple interconnected areas:
- Drinking water access and affordability
- Clean water protection
- Groundwater sustainability
- Ecosystem health and river restoration
- Flooding and drought resilience
- Urban green infrastructure
- Water equity advancement

### California Investment

California represents the Water Foundation's most substantially funded region:
- **284 grants** totaling **$17,041,640** (2020-2024)
- Approximately 71% of western regional grantmaking by dollar amount
- Total national investment: nearly $43 million to over 210 organizations

### Key California Policy Achievements Supported

- California Sustainable Groundwater Management Act (SGMA)
- California Open and Transparent Water Data Act
- Central Valley Flood Protection Plan
- Measure W (Safe Clean Water LA) - secured sustainable funding for green stormwater infrastructure
- California Safe and Affordable Drinking Water Fund (SAFER)
- California Consolidation of At-Risk Water Districts initiative

### Grant Process

**Critical:** The Water Foundation does not accept unsolicited proposals. Organizations are identified and invited by foundation staff or recommended through partner networks.

For invited grantees, the foundation provides:
- Multiyear commitments
- Support beyond the grant (networking, amplification)
- Capacity building and network development

### Contact Information

- **Headquarters:** Sacramento, California
- **Email:** info@waterfdn.org
- **Phone:** (916) 414-3310
- **Website:** waterfdn.org
- **Grants Database:** Available on website for research

### Safe, Clean Water LA Partnership

The Water Foundation partners with LA County Flood Control District to administer the Safe, Clean Water Public Education and Community Engagement Grants Program:
- **$8.5 million** available over funding cycle
- Supports education and community engagement related to stormwater capture
- Applications accepted September 24, 2024 through April 4, 2025
- Funds must be expended by July 31, 2026

# Water-Focused Foundations

## Pisces Foundation

The Pisces Foundation advances solutions to natural resource challenges through its distinctive "One Water" urban water strategy.

### Mission and Approach

The foundation pursues integrated and equitable water management, recognizing that:
- Water is linked to climate, ecosystems, human health, and social equity
- Solutions must use a systems lens considering interconnectivity
- One Water seeks to solve multiple challenges simultaneously
- Solutions are as diverse as the communities they serve

### Investment Record

- Over **$6 million** invested directly in organizations since 2014
- Supported One Water policies and programs in **21 cities** nationwide
- 2022 Urban Water RFP: **$780,000** to eight organizations across six cities

### 2022 Urban Water RFP Grantees

Recent grants demonstrate the foundation's focus on urban transformation:

| Organization | Location | Focus Area |
|-------------|----------|------------|
| Centro por la Justicia—Southwest Workers Union | San Antonio | Community-based One Water solutions |
| Groundwork San Diego—Chollas Creek | San Diego | Equitable green stormwater infrastructure |
| Miami Waterkeeper | Miami | One Water Action Plan for 34 municipalities |
| National Wildlife Federation/Bayou City Waterkeeper | Houston | First-ever One Water Plan |
| Verde and Oregon Water Futures | Portland | Tribal consultation in water/land planning |
| Water Collaborative of Greater New Orleans | New Orleans | Equitable stormwater funding |

### Eligibility Requirements

- U.S.-based 501(c)(3) public charities
- Consortia eligible (at least one 501(c)(3) anchor)
- Primary grantee must have smart water expertise
- Must include grassroots community-based organization involvement
- Meaningful community engagement required
- Project city/county must have population of at least 200,000

### Grant Parameters

- Typical awards: **$95,000-$125,000** per year
- Multi-year funding available (1-3 years)
- Additional cohort support funding ($150,000 for convenings/stipends)

### Application Process

1. Submit concept note (max 1,000 words) via email
2. Include: organization name, grant purpose, background, partners, context, goals, strategy, budget, funding partners
3. Submit as single PDF to: **water@piscesfoundation.org**
4. Selected applicants invited to submit full proposals

### Contact Information

- **Headquarters:** San Francisco, California
- **Phone:** 415-364-3760
- **General Email:** admin@piscesfoundation.org
- **Water Program:** water@piscesfoundation.org
- **Website:** piscesfoundation.org

# Water-Focused Foundations

## Spring Point Partners

Spring Point Partners champions community-driven change through an equity-centered approach to water sustainability.

### Mission and Approach

- Invests in transformational leaders, networks, and solutions
- Uses equity and social justice as guideposts for all decisions
- Integrates grant-making, impact investing, and professional development
- Matches support tools to each partner's specific needs

### Delta Program: Water Leadership Focus

The Delta program improves access to safe and affordable water by:
- Expanding community representation in utility leadership
- Ensuring water service decision-makers reflect communities served
- Identifying and elevating diverse leaders
- Supporting the next generation of municipal water leaders

### Key Partners in Delta Network

- US Water Alliance
- Urban Sustainability Directors Network
- Green Infrastructure Leadership Exchange
- Rural Community Assistance Partnership
- WaterNow Alliance
- Black Water Professionals Alliance
- Texas Water Foundation
- Environmental Policy Innovation Center

### California Involvement

While headquartered in Philadelphia, Spring Point Partners maintains California involvement through:
- Broader work on water sustainability and utility leadership transformation
- Focus on inclusive infrastructure workforce development
- Collaboration with Funders Network on workforce equity

### Grant Process

**Critical:** Spring Point Partners does not accept unsolicited proposals, requests, or appeals. The organization actively seeks out compatible partners aligned with their values and goals.

For selected partners, support may include:
- Grant funding
- Impact investment capital
- Capacity building support
- Professional development opportunities
- Custom combinations based on demonstrated needs

### Contact Information

- **Website:** thespringpoint.com
- **Media Inquiries:** press@thespringpoint.com
- **Contact Form:** thespringpoint.com/contact-us

# Water-Focused Foundations

## S.D. Bechtel, Jr. Foundation (Legacy - Concluded 2020)

The S.D. Bechtel, Jr. Foundation concluded operations in 2020 after contributing over $130 million in water program funds between 2009-2020.

### Historical Impact

The foundation envisioned a California that manages, stewards, and conserves its water and land for a resilient environment and healthy communities. Key contributions include:

- Over **$130 million** in program funds for sustainable water management
- Community Foundation Water Initiative (CFWI) launched in 2015
- Support for five regional community foundations addressing water
- Commissioned statewide report on land use, water, and equity integration

### Community Foundation Water Initiative (CFWI)

Brought together five regional community foundations:
1. San Francisco Foundation
2. Silicon Valley Community Foundation
3. Central Valley Community Foundation
4. California Community Foundation (Los Angeles)
5. The San Diego Foundation

### Key Lessons from CFWI

The foundation documented important lessons for future water philanthropy:
- Flexibility allows integration of water into existing work
- Multi-year investment allows initiatives to reach full potential
- Peer learning creates valuable knowledge sharing
- Initiative connections expand reach through collaboration
- Dedicated funding for coordination enables group learning

### Enduring Infrastructure

Though the foundation is closed, its legacy continues through:
- Strong organizations and partnerships carrying work forward
- Community foundations with water expertise
- Policy achievements supporting sustainable water management
- Documentation of lessons learned for future funders

# Water-Focused Foundations

## Resources Legacy Fund

Resources Legacy Fund (RLF) operates as architects of environmental progress through trusted partnerships and creative campaigns.

### Mission and Approach

RLF addresses three interconnected crises:
- Climate change
- Biodiversity loss
- Social inequities

The organization combines:
- Fiscal sponsorship of high-impact projects
- Campaign design and implementation
- Management of strategic grantmaking initiatives

### Water-Related Work

Water initiatives emerge from recognition that water challenges intersect with:
- Conservation goals (protecting water-dependent ecosystems)
- Climate resilience (adaptation and nature-based solutions)
- Environmental justice (community resilience to water impacts)

### Policy Achievements

RLF has contributed to:
- Over **$30 billion** in public funding for climate, water, and nature
- California's largest-ever climate bond (drought/flood protection)
- Hawaii's first "green fee" generating $100M/year for climate resilience

### Fiscally Sponsored Projects

Water-relevant projects include:
- Tribal Stewardship and Sovereignty Network
- National Ocean Protection Coalition
- Climate Mayors
- Center for Western Priorities

### Affiliated Organizations

- **Fund for a Better Future** (501(c)(4)): Expanded advocacy tools including lobbying and ballot measures
- **Shared Ascent Fund** (501(c)(3)): Voting rights, economic prosperity, health outcomes

### Financial Scale

- 2023 program expenses: approximately **$35.4 million**
- Hundreds of grants annually
- Focus on strategic partnerships rather than open applications

### Contact Information

- **Headquarters:** Sacramento, California
- **Phone:** 916-442-5057
- **Website:** resourceslegacyfund.org

# Water-Focused Foundations

## Strategic Recommendations for Accessing Foundation Funding

### Understanding Foundation Fit

| Foundation | Best For | Application Type |
|-----------|----------|------------------|
| Water Foundation | Systems-level water work, California focus | Invitation only |
| Pisces Foundation | Urban One Water transformation, major metros | Open RFP (periodic) |
| Spring Point Partners | Utility leadership, workforce equity | Invitation only |
| Resources Legacy Fund | Policy campaigns, fiscal sponsorship | Strategic partnerships |

### Building Visibility

For foundations without open applications:
1. Build impact and visibility within monitored networks
2. Attend convenings and conferences where foundation staff participate
3. Connect with existing grantees for potential introductions
4. Demonstrate alignment with foundation values through public work
5. Engage with foundation communications and shared learnings

### Application Strength Factors

Successful applications typically demonstrate:
- Clear theory of change
- Community engagement and voice in planning
- Equity outcomes explicitly addressed
- Systems-level thinking
- Potential for replication or scaling
- Strong partnerships across sectors

# Water-Focused Foundations

## Additional Resources

- **Water Foundation Grants Database:** Research past grants at waterfdn.org
- **Pisces Foundation Reports:** One Water strategy documentation at piscesfoundation.org
- **CFWI Documentation:** Lessons from Community Foundation Water Initiative available through community foundation websites

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Program Overview

The Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF) is a federal-state partnership established through Title VI of the Federal Clean Water Act of 1987. California's program is administered by the State Water Resources Control Board's Division of Financial Assistance.

### Key Statistics (FY 2024-25)
- **New loan commitments:** $679.3 million (152% increase from prior year)
- **Restricted net position:** $3.81 billion
- **Cumulative EPA funding received:** $4.24 billion
- **Cumulative state match provided:** $763.7 million

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Eligible Projects

### Core Project Categories
- **Wastewater Treatment:** Treatment plants, local sewers, sewer interceptors
- **Water Reclamation:** Recycled water treatment and distribution systems
- **Stormwater Management:** Both gray and green infrastructure solutions
- **Nonpoint Source Pollution:** Agricultural runoff, septic systems, brownfields
- **Estuary Protection:** San Francisco Bay, Morro Bay, Santa Monica Bay programs

### Green Infrastructure Solutions
- Green roofs, green streets, green walls
- Rainwater harvesting and infiltration basins
- Constructed wetlands and bioretention systems
- Permeable pavement surfaces
- Urban tree canopy establishment

### Emerging Contaminants
- PFAS treatment at publicly-owned treatment works
- Advanced treatment (reverse osmosis, granular activated carbon, ion exchange)
- Stormwater management for contaminant removal
- Microplastics capture and filtration systems

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Eligible Applicants

- Cities, towns, districts, and other public bodies
- State agencies
- Native American tribal governments and organizations
- 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations
- Designated management agencies under Section 208
- National Estuary Programs
- Watershed groups, community groups, homeowner's associations (for specific project types)

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Financing Terms

### Interest Rate
- **Rate calculation:** One-half of most recent General Obligation Bond rate
- **Current rate (Nov 2025):** 2.2%
- **Historical range:** 0.80% (Nov 2021) to 3.00% (Oct 2023)

### Loan Terms
- **Maximum term:** 30 years or project useful life (whichever is shorter)
- **Repayment start:** One year after construction completion
- **No maximum funding limit** per project
- **No maximum disbursement limit** per project

### Principal Forgiveness (Bipartisan Infrastructure Law)
- **General Supplemental Funding:** 49% must be principal forgiveness/grants
- **Emerging Contaminants Funding:** 100% as principal forgiveness (no loan required)

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Application Process

### Timeline
- Applications accepted continuously throughout calendar year
- Applications received by December 31 considered for next year's priority list
- **Goal:** 95% of complete applications receive financing agreement within 9 months
- **Disbursement goal:** 100% of requests paid within 30 days

### Required Packages
1. **General Package:** Project description and applicant information
2. **Environmental Package:** CEQA compliance, federal cross-cutting requirements
3. **Technical Package:** Engineering reports and design specifications
4. **Financial Package:** Budget and financial capacity demonstration

### Priority Scoring (Maximum 20 points)
| Category | Max Points | Criteria |
|----------|------------|----------|
| Project Score | 10 | Water quality resource/impact, corrective purpose |
| Secondary Score | 3 | Multiple environmental benefits, equivalency |
| Affordability Score | 5 | Community size, MHI, rate burden |
| Readiness Score | 2 | Plans/specs status, implementation readiness |

**FY 2025-26 Fundable List Cutoff:** 13 points

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Disadvantaged Community Support

### Definitions
- **Disadvantaged Community (DAC):** Population <10,000, MHI between 60-79% of statewide MHI
- **Severely Disadvantaged Community (SDAC):** Population <10,000, MHI <60% of statewide MHI

### Special Provisions
- Automatically fundable (no competitive scoring required)
- Enhanced principal forgiveness eligibility
- Higher priority ranking in scoring system
- Technical assistance available through Office of Sustainable Water Solutions

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Water Recycling Funding Program

The Water Recycling Funding Program (WRFP) operates as a complementary mechanism:
- Construction loans and grants
- Planning grants for feasibility evaluation
- **Grant amount:** 35% of reasonable construction cost
- **FY 2024-25 appropriation:** $69.8 million

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Key Contacts

- **Program website:** waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/srf/
- **Application portal:** Financial Assistance Application Submittal Tool (FAAST)
- **Interest rate history:** Published on Division of Financial Assistance website

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Federal Funding Sources

### Annual Allocations (FFY 2025)
| Source | Amount |
|--------|--------|
| Base Program | $113.5 million |
| BIL General Supplemental | $176.2 million |
| BIL Emerging Contaminants | $15.2 million |

### State Match Requirement
- **Base program:** 20% state match
- **BIL 2022-23:** 10% state match
- **BIL 2024-26:** 20% state match
- **Emerging contaminants:** 0% state match

# Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF)

## Recent Policy Updates (May 2025)

- Updated eligibility criteria for emerging contaminants projects
- Revised principal forgiveness allocation procedures
- Enhanced environmental review protocols
- Streamlined application and disbursement procedures
- Stormwater management funding cap: $20 million for SFY 2025-26

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Program Overview

The Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF) provides affordable financing for drinking water infrastructure projects throughout California. Established under the Safe Drinking Water Act of 1996, the program is administered by the State Water Resources Control Board's Division of Financial Assistance.

### Program Transfer History
- Originally managed by California Department of Health Services
- Transferred to State Department of Public Health
- Transferred to State Water Resources Control Board (July 1, 2014)

### Key Statistics
- **Total financial assistance executed:** Over $5.3 billion
- **Annual repayments to DWSRF:** Approximately $147.9 million
- **FY 2025-26 loan capacity:** $300 million (base program)
- **FY 2024-25 applications:** 47 new projects requesting over $2 billion

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Eligible Project Types

### Six Primary Categories

1. **Treatment Projects**
   - Water treatment plant construction/rehabilitation
   - Filtration system upgrades
   - Advanced treatment for contaminant removal
   - Compliance with new MCL requirements

2. **Transmission and Distribution**
   - Pipe rehabilitation and replacement
   - Service lateral extensions
   - Water meter installation
   - Booster pump stations

3. **Source Development**
   - New groundwater wells
   - Surface water source development
   - Wellhead protection programs
   - Source replacement for contaminated supplies

4. **Storage Facilities**
   - Finished water storage tank construction
   - Storage infrastructure rehabilitation
   - Water quality monitoring equipment

5. **Consolidation Projects**
   - System interconnections
   - Physical and managerial consolidations
   - Regional system integration

6. **New System Creation**
   - Serving homes with contaminated wells
   - Consolidating existing systems into regional systems

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Financing Terms

### Interest Rates (2025)
- **Standard rate:** 1.9% (50% of state GO Bond rate)
- **Historical comparison:** 2.3% (2024), 2.1% (2023), 1.1% (2022)

### Loan Terms by Community Type
| Community Type | Interest Rate | Max Term |
|----------------|---------------|----------|
| Small SDAC | 0% | 40 years |
| Small DAC (rates ≥1.5% MHI) | Reduced | 30-40 years |
| Standard | 50% of GO Bond rate | 30 years |

### Repayment Structure
- Construction loans: Up to 30 years or useful life
- Planning/design loans: Up to 10 years
- Negative interest rate loans available for extreme hardship

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Grant and Principal Forgiveness

### Maximum Amounts by Category

**Small DAC/SDAC/Expanded Small DAC (Category A-C and Consolidation):**
- Up to 100% of total eligible project cost
- $80,000 per connection standard maximum
- $100,000 per connection (Deputy Director approval for good cause)
- $120,000 per connection (mandatory consolidation/appointed administrator)

**Medium DAC (20,001-100,000 population, MHI <80% statewide):**
- Up to 50% of total eligible project cost
- $40,000 per connection maximum
- $5 million per project maximum
- Requires water rates ≥1.5% of MHI

**Emerging Contaminants:**
- $25 million per water system maximum
- No limit for DAC systems serving <25,000 people

**Planning Grants:**
- No cap on individual grant awards
- Count toward 5-year total assistance limit

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Priority Categories

### Project Ranking System
| Priority | Description | Example Issues |
|----------|-------------|----------------|
| A | Immediate health risk | Waterborne disease, contamination, treatment failure |
| B | Untreated at-risk sources | Vulnerable sources, emerging contamination |
| C | Compliance/supply needs | Standard violations, insufficient capacity |
| D | System reliability | Current compliance but inadequate reliability |
| E | Secondary risks | Water quality beyond primary standards |
| F | Other eligible | Efficiency improvements, asset management |

### FY 2024-25 Application Statistics
- Priority A: 30 applications, $98 million requested
- Priority B: 9 applications, $19.7 million requested
- Priority C: 103 applications, $498 million requested
- Total: 277 applications, $1.02 billion requested

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## SAFER Program Integration

The Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience (SAFER) program, established by Senate Bill 200 (2019), integrates with DWSRF:

### SAFER Funding
- **Annual allocation:** Up to $130 million through 2030
- **Total 10-year investment:** $1.4 billion
- **Source:** 5% of Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund

### SAFER Accomplishments (2019-2024)
- 321 water systems serving 3.3 million people came off Failing list
- 170 consolidations completed, benefiting 324,101 people
- Over $900 million in drinking water grants to DACs

### Current Status (Dec 2024)
- **Failing systems:** 390 serving 811,964 Californians
- **At-Risk systems:** 589 serving 1.49 million people
- **DAC concentration:** 79% of Failing systems serve DACs
- **Equity impact:** 52% serve majority communities of color

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Consolidation Incentives

### Receiving Water System Benefits

**Zero-Interest Financing:**
- Up to $10 million per consolidated community/system

**Grant Funding per Connection:**
| Consolidated System Type | Grant Amount |
|-------------------------|--------------|
| Non-DAC system | Up to $3,000/connection |
| Small DAC | Up to $5,000/connection |
| Small SDAC | Up to $10,000/connection |

**Maximum grant:** $1 million per consolidated community

**Managerial Consolidation:**
- Up to $2 million in 0% financing per project

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Application Process

### Submission Portal
- Financial Assistance Application Submittal Tool (FAAST)

### Required Components
1. **General Application:** System info, project description
2. **Environmental Application:** CEQA compliance
3. **Technical Application:** Engineering design
4. **Financial Application:** Funding sources, financial impacts

### Key Requirements
- Authorized Representative Resolution from governing body
- Opinion of bond/general counsel
- Technical, Managerial, Financial (TMF) Assessment
- Net revenue pledge and security interest

### Disbursement Process
- Planning/design: Available after Agreement execution
- Construction: Available after finalized Agreement with approved budget
- 30-day payment requirement after receipt of funds
- Retention limits: 70% until draft deliverables, 90% until final

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Federal Funding Allocations (FFY 2025)

| Program | Loan Funding | Principal Forgiveness |
|---------|--------------|----------------------|
| Base Program | $29.4 million | $57.7 million |
| IIJA General Supplemental | $16.6 million | $32.6 million |
| Lead Service Line Replacement | $7.2 million | $14.0 million |
| Emerging Contaminants | Per allocation | Per allocation |

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Lead Service Line Replacement

### Bipartisan Infrastructure Law Provisions
- $15 billion nationwide over five years
- California FFY 2022 allocation: $250 million
- FFY 2024-25 allocation: $28.7 million (reduced due to incomplete inventory reporting)

### Requirements
- 49% must be grants/forgivable loans to DACs
- Inventory development and submission required
- Focus on identification, replacement within ROW and private property

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Set-Asides (26% of Capitalization Grants)

| Set-Aside Category | Maximum | Purpose |
|--------------------|---------|---------|
| Administration & TA | 4% or $400K | Program admin, assistance to all systems |
| Small System TA | 2% | Exclusive assistance to systems ≤10,000 |
| State Program Management | 10% | Operator certification, capacity development |
| Local Assistance | 15% (10% max per activity) | Source protection, wellhead programs |

# Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)

## Key Contacts and Resources

- **Division of Financial Assistance:** waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/
- **SAFER Dashboard:** waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/saferdashboard.html
- **Local DDW District Offices:** Primary contact for project discussions
- **Office of Sustainable Water Solutions:** Technical assistance coordination

# SRF Funding for Small Communities

## Community Classification System

### Disadvantaged Community Definitions

| Classification | Abbreviation | MHI Threshold | Population |
|----------------|--------------|---------------|------------|
| Disadvantaged Community | DAC | ≤80% of statewide MHI | Any |
| Severely Disadvantaged Community | SDAC | ≤60% of statewide MHI | Any |
| Small Disadvantaged Community | Small DAC | ≤80% of statewide MHI | ≤10,000 |
| Small Severely Disadvantaged Community | Small SDAC | ≤60% of statewide MHI | ≤10,000 |
| Expanded Small DAC | - | ≤80% of statewide MHI | 10,001-20,000 |
| Small Non-DAC | - | ≤150% of statewide MHI | ≤10,000 |

### MHI Thresholds (Approximate FY 2024-25)
- **DAC threshold:** ~$60,000-65,000 (80% statewide MHI)
- **SDAC threshold:** ~$37,000-40,000 (60% statewide MHI)
- **Non-DAC threshold:** ~$112,000-120,000 (150% statewide MHI)

### Population Thresholds
- **Small community:** ≤10,000 people OR ≤3,300 service connections
